supportDesc.condition: Two gatherings missing at the beginning of the manuscript. The signatures suggest that a further gathering is missing between 5 and 11, but there do not appear to be gaps in the text. Gathering 28 is a later addition, with fol. 223r following logically from and in the same hand as fol. 214v.

binding.p: Standard Laudian binding, leather over pasteboard.
binding.condition: Boards partially detached. Clasps missing. Binding is excessively tight.
binding.decoNote: Laud’s coat of arms embossed in gold on the upper board.

history.origin: From Cirencester Abbey, third quarter of the twelfth century. The additions on fols 223r to 224v feature the abbot of Cirencester prominently, and portions appear to be written in the hand of Walter de Melida. A strip cut from the top of fol. 222v might have contained an ex-libris inscription, though it does not appear to read any variant of Cyrencestrie.
history.acquisition: Owned by William Laud. Fol. 1r, Liber Guil. Laud Archiepiscopi Cant. et Cancellar. uniuersit. Oxon. 1638.

msItem.title: ‘Parua glosatura’ on the psalms and canticles
Glossed Psalter
msItem.incipit: fol. 1ra Insuper etc. Sicut supra. insuper et usque ad noctem increpuerunt me. ut pro meo molestiarum⸵ sint modo gaudia humanitatis celestia.
fol. 1rb meum et exultauit lingua mea Ps 15:9
msItem.explicit: fol. 200rc cimbala inuicem se tangunt⸵ ut sonent. ideo labiis nostris comperantur. sed melius in cimbalis qui inuicem se honorantes⸵ dant laudem deo.

msItem.title: Glossed canticles 1–6
msItem.incipit: fol. 200v Quod ualet .xv. in ordine singulorum⸵ hoc .cl. in ordine denariorum. et mille quingenti. in ordine centenariorum.
msItem.explicit: fol. 210vb et propitius erit terre populi sui. Deut. 32:43
fol. 210vc Terre id est ecclesię. misericordiam suam ostendit.

listBibl.bibl: Margaret T. Gibson, ‘The Latin Apparatus’, in The Eadwine Psalter: Text, Image, and Monastic Culture in Twelfth-Century Canterbury, ed. Margaret T. Gibson, T.A. Heslop, and Richard W. Pfaff, Publications of the Modern Humanities Research Association 14 (London: Modern Humanities Research Association, 1992), 116 and pl. 38.

msItem.title: ‘Stavelot Commentary’ on the Athanasian Creed
msItem.incipit: fol. 211r Hic beatus athanasius liberum arbitrium posuit sicut dicit in psalmo.
msItem.rubric: fol. 211rb Fides sancti Athanasii episcopi catholica;
msItem.incipit: Quicumque uult saluus esse⸵ ante omnia opus est ut teneat catholicam fidem.
msItem.explicit: fol. 214r Subsistentia quid est? Subsistentia eo sensu dicitur. quo deum semper stare id est semper esse. non astando humani corporis consuetudine. sed a permanendo. quia semper permanet eo quod est.

listBibl.bibl: Andrew Eubank Burn, The Athanasian Creed and Its Early Commentaries, Texts and Studies: Contributions to Biblical and Patristic Literature 4.1 (Cambridge: University Press, 1896), lviii–l, 11–20.
Nikolaus M. Häring, ‘Commentaries on the Pseudo-Athanasian Creed’, Mediaeval Studies 34 (1972): 229.

msItem.title: Excerpts from the church fathers on the nature of psalms
msItem.incipit: fol. 214ra Ieronimus ad paulam et e. de beati inmaculati. Omnis moralis locus in hoc psalmo est comprehensus.
msItem.explicit: fol. 214vb nec minor in minoribus. nec in maioribus.
msItem.note: Added in another hand; continued on fol. 223r.

supportDesc.collation:
Some gatherings numbered in ink by the text hand on the first or last page of the gathering; cropped. Gathering 1 = .iii.; 2 = .iiii.; 3 = .v.; 4 = .vi.; 5 = .vii. (33r); 11 = .xiiii. (81r); 21 = .xxiiii. (161r).
A few cropped catchwords inked alongside signatures (e.g. fols. 16v, 24v, 72v) in the text hand at the foot of the last page of the gathering. Misericordia et caritas (gloss) pupillam oculi (text)

layoutDesc.layout: Text to be commented on written in the centre column in a larger script, every three lines. Glosses written in the outer columns and interlinear. Line spacing 4.5–5 mm. Ruled lightly in pencil; pricked on the outer edges.

handDesc.handNote: Gothic textualis, third quarter of the twelfth century. At least three scribes.

decoDesc.decoNote: Lombardic initials typical of those found in Cirencester manuscripts from the middle of the twelfth century in their style and colour. Each psalm begins with a 5-line initial, alternating between red, blue, golden, and sometimes green, usually with decoration in one of the opposite shades. Larger and more initials mark major divisions in the text, found on fols. 57r, 105r, 130v, 150v, 200v. Those on fols. 18r and 38r have penwork added, thought by Pächt and Alexander (no. 177) to be from the fourteenth century.
Titles of psalms and canticles in red (with that for the Athanasian Creed on fol. 211r written partially in a golden colour). Some lemmata in the commentary highlighted in golden.
New sections of the excerpts on fols. 214r–v and 223r open with enlarged Lombardic capitals in black.

physDesc.additions: Additional glosses added by contemporary hands. Occasional notes in a fourteenth-century cursive.

msItem.title: Litany and prayers for the dead with some music
msItem.incipit: fol. 216ra Kyrieleyson. Criste eleyson. Criste audi nos. Pater de celis deus miserent nobis. Fili redemptor muni deus⸵ miserere nobis.
msItem.filiation: Classed as Sarum 14–72–24 type in Ottosen, who dates it to the thirteenth century. The litany of the saints on fol. 215r–v includes many English examples, including Frideswide.

listBibl.bibl: Knud Ottosen, The Responsories and Versicles of the Latin Office of the Dead (Aarhus, Denmark: Aarhus University Press, 1993), 115.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in plummet; line spacing 6.5–7 mm. Sections intended to be set to music are written in a smaller script, every other line. Pricked on the outer edges.

handDesc.handNote: Gothic textualis, second half of the thirteenth century.

physDesc.musicNotation: On fol. 217v, square notation written on four red staff lines. Space left for notation on fols. 218v–222v, but only the words have been completed.

decoDesc.decoNote: Each new prayer opens with a two-line Lombardic initial, alternating between red and dark blue, with penwork in the opposite colour. Phrases in the litany open with enlarged capitals, alternating between red and blue. Rubrics in red.

msItem.title: Excerpts from the church fathers on the nature of psalms (continuing from 214v)
msItem.incipit: fol. 214ra Ieronimus. Diapsalma quidam hebreum uerbum esse uolunt.
msItem.explicit: quia ideo interponitur. ut conuersio sensuum uel personarum esse noscatur;

msItem.title: Letters of proxy, appeal, commission, etc.

msItem.incipit: Viris uenerabilibus etc. E. dictus prior Cirec’ et Eiusdem loci Conuentus salutem etc. Quamuis hac instanti die iouis coram uobis apud Winton’
msItem.explicit: adiudicauimus. Hinc est quod uobis tanquam ordina

msItem.note: Figures named include Master Robert of Bingham, Master Robert of Clipston, Alexander Neckam; placing the documents in the reign of King John.

listBibl.bibl: Described in C.R. Cheney, English Bishops’ Chanceries, 1100–1250, Publications of the Faculty of Arts of the University of Manchester 3 (Manchester: University Press, 1950), 129–130.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in pencil, with the inner column tending to be wider than the outer. Line spacing 4-5.5 mm.

handDesc.handNote: Written in three or four charter hands, first quarter of the thirteenth century.

decoDesc.decoNote: The first set of items added begin with two-line initials, alternating between red, green, and blue.
